title: 105_s2347
content: The Act may be cited as the Comprehensive Methamphetamine Abuse Reduction Act and aims to expand prevention efforts for methamphetamine abuse. The Comprehensive Methamphetamine Abuse Reduction Act aims to expand prevention efforts for methamphetamine abuse by allowing the Director of the Center for Substance Abuse Prevention to make grants for school-based and community-based programs focused on preventing methamphetamine abuse and addiction. The Comprehensive Methamphetamine Abuse Reduction Act allows funds to be used for planning, establishing, or administering methamphetamine prevention programs in schools and communities targeting high-risk populations. The Comprehensive Methamphetamine Abuse Reduction Act funds community-based prevention programs targeting at-risk populations, assists local government entities in prevention activities, educates law enforcement officials on signs of abuse, and supports monitoring and evaluation of prevention activities. The Director prioritizes grants for rural and urban areas with high rates of methamphetamine abuse. Funding is allocated for prevention activities, monitoring, evaluation, and pilot programs to encourage innovation. Additionally, a portion of the budget is reserved for analyses and evaluation in consultation with other federal agencies. The Director allocates funding for prevention programs and evaluations of methamphetamine abuse. $500,000 is designated for analyses and evaluations, with annual reports submitted to specific committees. $20,000,000 is authorized for program implementation. An annual report is submitted to specific committees. $20,000,000 is authorized for program implementation. SEC. 3. EXPANDING CRIMINAL PENALTIES AND LAW ENFORCEMENT FUNDING. The United States Sentencing Commission will amend sentencing guidelines for offenses related to methamphetamine production in accordance with federal laws. This includes increasing the base offense level for such offenses. The United States Sentencing Commission will increase the base offense level for offenses related to methamphetamine production in accordance with federal laws, including those that pose a substantial risk to health and safety. The United States Sentencing Commission will increase the base offense level for offenses related to methamphetamine production that pose a substantial risk to health and safety, by not less than level 27. The United States Sentencing Commission will increase the base offense level for methamphetamine production offenses to level 30 or higher. The Sentencing Commission must implement these guidelines promptly after the enactment of the Act. The amendments will apply to offenses occurring 60 days after the Act's enactment. Additionally, increased resources are authorized for combating methamphetamine trafficking in designated high-intensity drug areas. Increased resources are authorized for combating methamphetamine trafficking in designated high-intensity drug areas. $25,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 1999, and necessary sums for fiscal years 2000 through 2004. SEC. 4. Treatment of methamphetamine abuse. Section 507 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to allow grants for expanding treatment programs for methamphetamine abuse and addiction. Funds can be used for evidence-based programs to help individuals quit methamphetamine use. The amended Section 507 of the Public Health Service Act allows grants for expanding treatment programs for methamphetamine abuse and addiction. Funds can be used for evidence-based programs, training health professionals in recognizing and treating methamphetamine abuse, and planning educational activities related to treatment. The Director shall prioritize funding for expanding treatment programs for methamphetamine abuse and addiction, including planning, administration, educational activities, monitoring, evaluation, reporting, pilot programs, and coordination with mental health services. Priority in grants will be given to areas experiencing high rates of methamphetamine abuse. Additionally, funding will support analyses and evaluations of effective treatments and strategies for disseminating information on treatment services. The Director will conduct periodic analyses and evaluations of treatments for methamphetamine abuse, develop strategies for disseminating treatment information, and submit an annual report to specified committees. $40,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 1999, with additional funding for succeeding years. SEC. 5. EXPANDING METHAMPHETAMINE RESEARCH. Section 464N of the Public Health Service Act is amended to allow grants for interdisciplinary research on methamphetamine abuse and addiction, focusing on its effects on the human body, addictive nature, connection to mental illness, and prevention methods. The Director shall disseminate research results on methamphetamine abuse and addiction, including effects on individuals, connection to mental illness, prevention methods, treatment options, risk factors, effects on pregnant women and fetuses, and reasons for abuse. The Director will disseminate research results on methamphetamine abuse and addiction, including effects, prevention, treatment, risk factors, and reasons for abuse. Authorization of appropriations is provided for funding.
